message: (And whilst we're at it, it shouldn't use --background and --make-pidfile; see start-stop-daemon(8) pidfile)
There should be rm -f  $CELERY_PIDFILE_WHATEVER in the stop action too.

I'm having issues getting Celery to run as a daemon. I had it working at one point, but now it fails, so I'm looking for ideas about what could be causing it! To cross-post my serverfault question: http://serverfault.com/questions/254260/trouble-running-python-celery-as-a-daemon
From a reading of the initscript, I think think you have stale pidfile - delete /var/run/celeryd.pid and start it again?

if I remove --background, it throws a Python import error. Even though I'm using start-stop-dameon's --chdir option, it's not finding the files in that directory. So I'm going to try to add them to the path elsewhere for the moment... see if that takes.
I *think* this has something to do with paths
yeah, no luck with removing .pid before hand ... although I did notice it wasn't getting removed.
Turns out it was just permissions issues. The tasks/config files were not readable by celery. Only found it out by removing the --background bit, so thank you!
